CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 18, 1949, p. 4, reads: "Accused Policemen Cleared by Trial Board - Mother and Accused Son...Mrs. Olive Jackson is pictured giving motherly word of cheer to son, Karl C. [O.], as they awaited trial board hearing on charges made against the traffic officer by Clark Watts. Mrs. Jackson is notary public in Hill District.  Officer Jackson has been given police citation for singlehandedly capturing three bandits in July, 1948.  He has been assigned to traffic bureau for six years, and was first Negro officer to have such assignment - Harris Photo."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Clark Watts Denies Politics Influenced Filing of Charges - Witnesses of All Races Crowd Trial Room; Wait Throughout Five-Hour Session to Defend Character of Officers Jackson and Hicks - 'Big Brass' of the city's police department, headed by Col. George E. A. Fairley, director of public safety, heard a public airing. Wednesday, of charges that two Hill District police officers were 'aiding and abetting hoodlumism' against a legitimate businessman whom they had allegedly tried to force into the rackets.  The hearing, attended my more than fifty Herron Avenue district businessmen and citizens brought together for the first time Officers Karl C. [O.] Jackson and John Hicks, and their accuser, Clark Watts.  Mrs. Watts is the owner of the Watts' Brothers Cleaner Shop, 2931 Wylie Avenue, an establishment he claimed was coveted by the officers who wished to use it for illegal and illicit purposes..."
TitMainTitle: Police officer Karl O. Jackson standing beside his mother Ora Jackson, with Rev. Charles Foggie seated on right
